text:
Part of the responsibility
of being a business owner

is to create
opportunities for others.

Every day, I'm fortunate
to be able to just

be a living witness of
what happens when families

stick together, see
opportunity, put in the work,

and are able to bring other
folks into the fold to carry
on the business legacy.

I want to take my
business into the future.

And the physical guard services
are not going to get us there.

As a small business,
she's got three issues

she's got to think about
in terms of scaling.

Should she double
down and continue

to focus on the New
York market, should

she think about
geographic expansion,

or should she think
about entering
a new area of cybersecurity?

Some of my advisors
on the corporate side

always talk about the next
big security emergency is not
going to be a physical one.
It's going to be a cyber one.

I understand what I know
and what I don't know.

Ego gets in the way of making
good business decisions.

One of the tests
of better leaders

is knowing when to be quiet and
take the advice of someone else,
even if it's not what you think.

The key to success is managing
all the family dynamics.

You somehow got
to figure out how

to divorce the emotion from the
decisions that you're making.

And that can be
very, very tough.

But if you have a
strong support network

of other business-minded
people who

have access, who
are plugged in, that

can advise your children,
your grandchildren,

that helps to create
those conversations when
it gets difficult.

Should she decide
to either acquire

another business or a joint
venture with a business,

it's important that
she find a partner that
shares the same values.

And how do we do it
at a consistent level,

demonstrating excellence
so that people
want to do business with us?
